div.p: SALII, in Roman antiquity, prieſts of Mars, whereof there were 12, inſtituted by Numa, wearing painted, particoloured garments, and high bonnets; with a ſteel cuiraſſe on the breaſt. They were called falii , from ſaltare “to dance;” becauſe, after aſſiſting at ſacrifices, they went dancing about the ſtreetε, with bucklers in their left-hand, and a rod in their right, ſtriking muſically with their rods on one another’s bucklers, and ſinging hymns in honour of the gods.
